div1.p: REPORT ON VISIT TO BOSTON AND NEW YORK. JANUARY 11-18, 1907. ******

The Catholic movement seems to have produced the most excellent results upon the President and the Secretary of State as well as upon the Senate, and I am specifically glad to be able to report the success of my mission to Boston which is not only the centre of the anti- Congo agitation but is also the home of the electors of Senator Lodge who has brought in the Resolution against us.

Boston is the centre of the Baptist missionary societies and of many fantastic "reforms" movements but there is also a strong and growing Catholic element there whose influence in politics is sought even by Senator Lodge and other "puritans". During my visit to Boston I have been fortunate enough to interest the strong Catholic element in our cause and to around them to active work in our behalf.

His Grace, Monsignor O'Connell, Archbishop of Boston, received me most sympathetically and has promised me his support. The Catholic "Federation" of that district has already sent to the President and to the Senate a petition in our behalf.

Last Monday night in Boston I met the High Council of the Massachusetts Catholic Order of Foresters, which represents one hundred thousand of Senator Lodge's electors and as a result, chiefly through the sympathetic aid of the Rev/Father O'Neil, Spiritual Advisor of the Order, they took up the cause of the Congo and adopted resolutions in our favor which were at once transmitted to the President of the United States, the Secretary of State, to the Senate, to Mr. Lodge, and other

Senators. The Order of Foresters also desire that a copy of their resolution should be presented to His Majesty, and I have the honor to transmit a copy herewith, with the suggestion that some acknowledgment and response be sent the Order through us, as soon as possible.

The Boston "Alumni Sodality" also took a great interest in the matter. The question was presented to them throught the Rev. Father Dennis T. O'Sullivan who has spoken publicly in favor of the Congo on several occasions. I understand that the "Alumni Sodality" is sending to the Government petitions in our favor as a society and that the individual members are also working for us.

The Catholic Union which has among its members some of the most important Catholic citizens of Boston has also taken up our cause. They will have a lecture and discussion on the Congo as soon as possible and will then probably adopt resolutions similar to the resolutions adopted by other Catholic societies. The President of the Catholic Union has taken a person interest and may be expected to aid us in every way possible.

The "Federation" of Boston is to hold a meeting tonight (January 20) to discuss the French Church question and also the Congo and still further action may be expected from them to promote our interests.

I also had several meetings with Mr. Matthew Cummings, the President of the Irish Society known as the "Ancient Order of Hibernians". He is an important politician in Boston and the Hibernians constitute a well-known and influential society of about two hundred thousand men. He manifests a deep interest in our case and promised me to bring the matter up before the High Counil of the Order last night, when they probably will have adopted resolutions in our favor to be sent to the President, Secretary of State and the Senate.

It seems thus that we have aroused a strong element in our favor in Boston and have, by my visit there, secured the active help of between three hundred thousand and four hundred thousand of Mr. Lodge's own electors. This is sure to have a good effect on Lodge as well as us on the other Senators. We have secured a strong support even in the midst of the enemy's camp.
In addition to this aid from the State of Massachusetts I have been able, through the help of the Rev. Father Shanley, to secure important assistance from the neighboring State of Connecticut.

Petitions to the President and to the Senate were sent, at my request, form several Catholic Association of that State, among others from the "St. Peters Corporate Society" numbering nearly five thousand members, and the matter is brought to the attention of other societies which may be expected to act soon.

In addition to these societies I was enabled while on this trip to get into communication with the "Catholic Young Men's National Union" numbering fifty thousand, which without loss of time, sent an expression of its sentiments in our favor to Washington by telegram.

Father Shanley also requested the "Catholic Temperance Association Union of America" which has ninety thousand members to take similar action. I have not yet received offical notice but it is probably that they have taken the requested action by this time.

In New York i found that the agitation which we had started amont among the Catholic societies is still continuing satistisfactorily and I am endeavoring to encourage the movement there as much as possible.

The Catholic movement has not only intimidated our enemies in the Senate and encouraged our friends in the same body, but it has also encouraged our friends everywhere and especially our friends in the new Concessionary companies who seem now disposed to work harder for us politically than they were four years ago at the time of the Kowalski-Wack publications. I seized the opportunity while in New York to urge them to greater endeavor. I think that the very fact of the existence of the American Concessionary Companies has been an influence in our favor and has had some effect in making the Government and the Senate more conservative but I hope now to get the people interested in the companies to work more actively. At my suggestion the American-Congo Company has employed as one of its agents Mr. S.P. Verner, who has been in the Congo several years and whose name is well known to the Chevalier de Cuvelier. As Verner is impartial and honest and knows about the true condition of the Congo I have urged upon the Company that they should allow Verner to go to Washington at once and see the President, the Secretary of State and various Senators in order to put the true state of affairs before them.
I have found every where I have been in this country in the past four weeks that the defence of the King Sovereign's administration by Cardinal Gibbons has made a deep and lasting impression.

I feel assured that it is the Catholic movement that has held the Senate in check for the past several weeks. The Resolutions of Societies, and the petitions of individuals, as well as certain person influence and personal letter written by friends of Senators have undoubtedly produced a very favorable effect. If we can continue the movement with sufficient vigor we may be able to avert any action by Congress, but, in any event, the expression of opinion which we have placed before Congress and before the Government is sure to have a decided effect in modifying any hostile action which the Government may have momentarily comtemplated while under the pressure of the Baptist and other Protestant missionaries.

While on this trip in the North I have still continued to keep in communication with the individuals and societies in the West whom I visited two weeks ago, and I shall continue to encourage them to keep up the movement they have started in favor of the Congo.
James Gustavus Whiteley Consul General.
